categories.name: Great Walls of China: Beyond the Stone

questions.clue: For 200 points: This dynasty is credited with building the first sections of the Great Wall, primarily using rammed earth.
For 400 points: This Canadian city is home to a replica of the Great Wall of China, located in a park named after its sister city, Beijing.
For 600 points: Besides stone and earth, this sticky substance was used as a binding agent during some periods of the Wall's construction.
For 800 points: Contrary to popular belief, the Great Wall is not a single continuous wall but rather a series of these.
For 1000 points: In 1987, the Great Wall was inscribed as a UNESCO World Heritage Site, a recognition that highlighted its significance in this field.

categories.name: Canadian Literature: From Coast to Coast

questions.clue: For $200, this Canadian author wrote 'The Handmaid's Tale', which was adapted into an award-winning TV series.
For $400, 'Anne of Green Gables' is set on this eastern Canadian island province.
For $600, this author of Chinese descent wrote 'The Jade Peony', a novel set in Vancouver's Chinatown.
For $800, 'The Book of Negroes' by Lawrence Hill explores the journey of a woman from Africa to Nova Scotia during this historical period.
For $1000, this Canadian novel by Paul Quarrington, titled after a sport popular in Canada, won the Governor General's Award in 1989.
This Canadian 'Great One' is widely regarded as the greatest hockey player of all time, holding numerous NHL records.
Known for his powerful slapshot, this Montreal Canadiens legend won 11 Stanley Cups during his career.
This Chinese-Canadian player became the first Chinese-born player to score a point in the NHL, playing for the Washington Capitals in 1948.
A former captain of the Detroit Red Wings, this Canadian defenseman is known for his leadership and winning 4 Stanley Cups with the team.
This Canadian goaltender, known as 'The China Wall,' was the first NHL netminder to score a goal by shooting the puck into the opposing team's net.

categories.name: Culinary Capitals: A World of Flavors

questions.clue: This Canadian city is known for its diverse culinary scene, including poutine and maple syrup treats.
Famous for its Sichuan cuisine, this Chinese city offers spicy dishes like mapo tofu and hot pot.
In this Canadian city, you can enjoy fresh Pacific seafood and the famous Japadog.
This Chinese city is the birthplace of dim sum and offers a vibrant street food scene.
Known as the 'Paris of the Prairies', this Canadian city is celebrated for its farm-to-table cuisine.
This fundamental force keeps a hockey puck sliding along the ice in Canada.
Named after a Chinese physicist, this paradox suggests that two identical particles cannot occupy the same quantum state.
This effect, first observed with a hockey puck, explains why objects appear to bend when they pass through media of different densities.
Canada's Sudbury Neutrino Observatory helped confirm the oscillation of these particles, solving a long-standing solar mystery.
This Chinese-born physicist's experiment confirmed the violation of parity conservation in weak nuclear interactions.

final.clue: This country, known for its prowess in winter sports, won its first Olympic gold medal in men's hockey at the Winter Games held in China in 2022.
